comments:
Hallo,

I made some tests with CDT 2.1 RC0 and detected the following problem. 

We use Eclipse / CDT on a PC with windows XP using cygwin and the Gnu tools to 
create applications for a small realtime kernel in a host / target environment. 
In this scenario we also make a remote connection to a debug server on our 
realtime target. This worked well before. 

Now with the actual release we receive an error, when we want to start the 
debug session:

!SUBENTRY 1 org.eclipse.cdt.launch 4 107 Nov 03, 2004 15:54:17.679
!MESSAGE Program not Binary
!STACK 0
java.io.FileNotFoundException: Program not Binary
	at org.eclipse.cdt.launch.AbstractCLaunchDelegate.verifyBinary
(AbstractCLaunchDelegate.java:747)
	at org.eclipse.cdt.launch.internal.LocalRunLaunchDelegate.launch
(LocalRunLaunchDelegate.java:58)
	at org.eclipse.debug.internal.core.LaunchConfiguration.launch
(LaunchConfiguration.java:569)
	at org.eclipse.debug.internal.core.LaunchConfiguration.launch
(LaunchConfiguration.java:150)
	at org.eclipse.debug.internal.ui.DebugUIPlugin.buildAndLaunch
(DebugUIPlugin.java:792)
	at org.eclipse.debug.internal.ui.DebugUIPlugin$6.run
(DebugUIPlugin.java:955)
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:66)

The binary parser is set to gnu elf / elf. Our executable is a relocatable i386-
elf file. This file will be interpreted correctly when we look at it using the 
CDT navigation window. I also created a new project - but the same results. 
Something must have changed with this release.

If necessary I can provide additional information (object files).

Regards. Manfred.

Can you debug this method to dig further, I don't see anything obvious. If your
binaries show up in the C/C++ Project view as binaries, then the launch should
detect them as such.
